docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN she was 32, Dr. Amy E. Newburger had a skin cancer, something the dermatologist thought would never happen to her. When she was about 45, she realized that she was aging and wondered if her professional effectiveness would be diminished by looking old. Dr. Newburger, a Scarsdale resident, set out to see what she could do to maintain a healthy, youthful appearance. Now 49, she has written a book, ''Looking Good at Any Age'' (Doubleday), in which she discusses how the skin works, makeup and cosmetic procedures and the psychological issues relating to the quest for the fountain of youth. The book's co-author is Pam Proctor, a freelance writer from Vero Beach, Fla. The book should be available in a month or so.

headline.main: Q&A/Dr. Amy E. Newburger; How to Keep Looking Good at Any Age

docs.abstract: Dermatologist Amy E Newburger, co-author of book Looking Good at Any Age, answers questions about book and what she does to combat aging process; photo (Q & A column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The recent decision by UnitedHealth Group, a big managed care company, to let doctors treat patients without interference might mark the death of one reviled tactic of managed care. No longer will United have to approve, in advance, procedures that doctors have recommended to their patients. Doctors resented the need for such clearance as an intolerable interference by unqualified outsiders, and patients resented any denials as cost-saving by the insurance company at the expense of their health. To United's surprise, the advance approvals were not even saving any money, so it ended the practice. But if the managed care companies abandon the requirement for approval in advance, they will have to come up with effective alternatives. Two less incendiary options are already available. Someone needs to put a lid on physician charges. That someone, the market appears to be saying, should be the physicians themselves.
docs.abstract: Editorial says UnitedHealth Group's decision to allow doctors to treat patients without interference may end one reviled tactic of managed care, but warns that managed care companies will have to come up with effective alternatives to contain costs

docs.lead_paragraph: IN March, Dr. Archelle Georgiou, chief medical officer at UnitedHealthcare, called together 18 clinical managers from around the nation to spell out a significant shift in policy. Doctors, they were told, would no longer be forced to seek approval for treatments. Instead, the emphasis would be on meeting patients' medical needs effectively. The idea met with some skepticism. Many of those at the meeting, she said, sat with arms firmly folded across their chests. And body language soon gave way to more concrete criticism. In the hallway, she heard comments like, ''This will never work.''
docs.abstract: Article on UnitedHealthCare's decision, prompted by chief medical officer Dr Archelle Georgiou, to no longer force doctors to seek approval for treatments and instead, emphasize meeting patients' medical needs effectively; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO days after non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a form of cancer, was diagnosed in her, Julie Lerner asked a doctor whether she could still have children. According to Ms. Lerner, his terse, unemotional reply was: ''Why are you worried about that? You might not live.'' Throughout a long battle with cancer beginning seven years ago, when she was 26, Ms. Lerner was frustrated by what she saw as a lack of sympathy and understanding from hospitals, doctors and insurance companies. One day in early 1997, after leaving a hospital's especially bureaucratic billing department, Ms. Lerner opened her Zagat Survey to make restaurant reservations for that evening in Manhattan.

headline.main: An Entrepreneurial Spirit In a Health Network Guide

docs.lead_paragraph: On a recent morning, Judy Wessler, who runs a nonprofit watchdog group, visited five children's health clinics situated in housing projects in the South Bronx. But she did not have much luck getting in. At the John Mitchell Child Health Clinic at 185 Willis Avenue, the black metal door was shuttered. A metal grate covered the entrance of the Forest Houses Child Health Clinic at 1001 East Tinton Street in the Forest Neighborhood Houses. And although the lights were on outside the clinic in Adams Houses on East 152nd Street, the door was locked and the space dark. All three have been closed for renovations by the city.

headline.main: Doors Are Shuttered at a Cluster of Child Health Clinics

docs.abstract: Child health advocates, including Commission on the Public's Health System head Judy Wessler, complain when New York City shuts five child health clinics at same time for renovations; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Bitter Pills for Ailing Hospitals'' (front page, Oct. 31), by Milt Freudenheim, looked at the drastic cost-cutting measures often recommended by the Hunter Group, a consulting firm led by David Hunter. The article drew various responses from readers. To the Editor: The fundamental issue that neither the hospital administrators nor the doctors of our country have grasped is that, as deliverers of health care, they have too often abandoned their role as patients' defenders and advocates. Hospitals and doctors have systematically refused to change the way they take care of patients.
docs.abstract: Health Network America chairman Stephen A Kardos letter on Milt Freudenheim's October 31 article on hospital cost-cutting measures contends that hospital administrators and doctors often abandon their role as patients' defenders and advocates (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Bitter Pills for Ailing Hospitals'' (front page, Oct. 31), by Milt Freudenheim, looked at the drastic cost-cutting measures often recommended by the Hunter Group, a consulting firm led by David Hunter. The article drew various responses from readers. To the Editor: Hospitals bring in the Hunter Group to solve their problems. But those problems were often created, hand in hand, with other consultants hired by the very hospital boards and administrators who are now in trouble.

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY are pouring into Seattle this weekend in vans and on buses, by air and on foot -- the college students and the church groups, the environmental campaigners, the Teamsters, Ralph Nader, Chinese dissidents and the man who became a hero in France for defacing a McDonald's. All of them say they are outraged at the growing power of a group few even heard about five years ago, the World Trade Organization. And so, with tens of thousands massing, they are planning to turn what initially sounded like the yawner of all international meetings -- a gathering of trade ministers from 135 countries to start the ''Millennium Round'' of trade liberalization talks -- into the Woodstock of the era of globalization.

headline.main: The World: Big Blur; Meet Your Government, Inc.

docs.abstract: Tens of thousands of people are pouring into Seattle to demonstrate during World Trade Organization meeting, and express their outrage at growing power of group few people even knew about five years ago; WTO has become bureaucratic metaphor for view that markets have become real governing force of 1990's, with willing participation of governments and politicians; real target is blurring of roles of private and public sector, now that latter has increasingly become champion of private enterprise (M)

The article drew various responses from readers. To the Editor: The Hunter Group has developed a pattern for its recommendations: minimize unprofitable services, reduce staff, close entire units.

docs.lead_paragraph: In secret negotiations, Gov. George E. Pataki is pushing his Democratic rivals in the Legislature to cut Medicaid spending steeply as part of a deal to preserve a program that pays hospitals billions of dollars to treat uninsured patients and train doctors, according to people involved in the talks. The $2.7 billion state program is set to expire at the end of the year, and Mr. Pataki has not said exactly what he plans to do about it. But Democrats and representatives of the health care workers' unions privately say that the governor is using the program's looming expiration to try to force reductions in Medicaid -- across-the-board cuts that he has sought nearly every year in office, usually without success.

headline.main: Pataki Seeks a Trade-Off With Democrats to Cut Medicaid

docs.abstract: Informed sources say that Gov George E Pataki, in secret negotiations, is pushing his Democratic rivals in Legislature to cut Medicaid spending steeply as part of deal to preserve program that pays hospitals billions of dollars to treat uninsured patients and train doctors (M)
